answers.question: How much do you know about investing?
answers.answer: I'm knowledgeable, but wouldn't consider myself an expert

answers.question: How much control do you want to have over your asset allocation (i.e. whether the underlying investments are in stocks or bonds or other investments)?

options.text: Robo Advisers typically do not give the level of customisation over asset allocation that you are looking for.
Superannuation funds typically do not give the level of customisation over asset allocation that you are looking for.
Robo Advisers typically do not give the level of customisation over asset allocation that you are looking for.

answers.question: How much control do you want to have over the individual investments (eg stocks or bonds)?
answers.answer: I would like a professional to work out which stocks to buy, but I want to be able to veto stocks or make small changes

options.text: Online brokers are typically for someone looking for a lot of control over individual investments. Your answer suggests that you may instead be looking for a professional to help you manage your investment, if so an online broker may not be appropriate.
Robo Advisers typically do not give the level of customisation over individual investments that you are looking for.
Exchange Traded Funds buy a basket of stocks for you. You cannot change the basket.

Superannuation funds typically do not give the level of customisation over individual investments that you are looking for. Some allow investors to add stocks to the portfolio, but with tight restrictions. They do not allow you to exclude stocks / sectors.
Very few financial planners provide the level of control over investments you are looking for.
Managed funds or Listed Investment Companies buy a basket of stocks for you. You cannot change the basket.

Online brokers are typically for someone looking for a lot of control over individual investments. Your answer suggests that you may instead be looking for a professional to help you manage your investment, if so an online broker may not be appropriate.
Robo Advisers typically do not give the level of customisation over individual investments that you are looking for.
Very few financial planners provide the level of control over investments you are looking for.
Exchange Traded Funds buy a basket of stocks for you. You cannot change the basket.
Very few financial planners provide the level of control over investments you are looking for.
Managed funds or Listed Investment Companies buy a basket of stocks for you. You cannot change the basket.

answers.question: How much transparency do you want into what you own?
answers.answer: I want to know the asset allocation (i.e. am I invested in stocks or bonds or private equity etc), but don't care if I don't see the details. I don't mind if it is out of date and only (say) every three months.

options.text: Superannation funds may provide the asset allocation. Some superannuation funds have their own definition, which can differ to common assessments - for example some funds call unlisted assets defensive, many investors disagree.

answers.question: How much are you willing to pay?

options.text: Nucleus Super fees tend to be a little over 1%, although they are lower than 1% for larger balances.

SMSFs have fixed accounting / admin costs each year. Some robo advisers may fit into your cost range. You may need to check the fees to confirm. Make sure that you include the Indirect Cost Ratio, also known as the ICR. Many robo advisers will not explicitly show this cost.

The fees on exchange traded funds vary widely. Most funds that buy assets on developed stock markets like the S&P 500 or the ASX 200 index tend to be less than 0.5%. Some funds are considerably more expensive. An SMSF will likely also cost you $1,000 to $5,000 in additional accountancy and compliance costs.
Stockbrokers typically cost more than this. An SMSF will likely also cost you $1,000 to $5,000 in additional accountancy and compliance costs.
Financial Planners typically cost more than your cost range. An SMSF will likely also cost you $1,000 to $5,000 in additional accountancy and compliance costs.

The fees on Managed funds or Listed Investment Companies vary widely. Some funds are less than 1%. Many are more expensive. An SMSF will likely also cost you $1,000 to $5,000 in additional accountancy and compliance costs.

Most robo advisers will fit into your cost range. You may need to check the fees to confirm. Make sure that you include the Indirect Cost Ratio, also known as the ICR. Many robo advisers will not explicitly show this cost.
Financial Planners typically cost more than your cost range.

The fees on exchange traded funds vary widely. Most funds that buy assets on developed stock markets like the S&P 500 or the ASX 200 index tend to be less than 0.5%. Some funds are considerably more expensive.
Stockbrokers typically cost more than this.
Financial Planners typically cost more than your cost range.
The fees on Managed funds or Listed Investment Companies vary widely. Some funds are less than 1%. Many are more expensive.

answers.question: How much do you have to invest?

options.text: SMSFs have fixed accounting / admin costs each year. ASIC suggests less than $500,000 in assets may be inappropriately small to successfully run an SMSF.
SMSFs have fixed accounting / admin costs each year. ASIC suggests less than $500,000 in assets may be inappropriately small to successfully run an SMSF.
SMSFs have fixed accounting / admin costs each year. ASIC suggests less than $500,000 in assets may be inappropriately small to successfully run an SMSF.

Many stock brokers will not deal with clients who have under $500,000 in investments. With your investment level, you may find that a stock broker won't take you on as a client or will give you a reduced service product. SMSFs have fixed accounting / admin costs each year. ASIC suggests less than $500,000 in assets may be inappropriately small to successfully run an SMSF.

Many financial planners will not deal with clients who have under $500,000 in investments. With your investment level, you may find that a financial planner won't take you on as a client or will give you a reduced service product. SMSFs have fixed accounting / admin costs each year. ASIC suggests less than $500,000 in assets may be inappropriately small to successfully run an SMSF.
SMSFs have fixed accounting / admin costs each year. ASIC suggests less than $500,000 in assets may be inappropriately small to successfully run an SMSF.

Many financial planners will not deal with clients who have under $500,000 in investments. With your investment level, you may find that a financial planner won't take you on as a client or will give you a reduced service product.

Many stock brokers will not deal with clients who have under $500,000 in investments. With your investment level, you may find that a stock broker won't take you on as a client or will give you a reduced service product.

Many financial planners will not deal with clients who have under $500,000 in investments. With your investment level, you may find that a financial planner won't take you on as a client or will give you a reduced service product.
